question.text: Sickle cell anaemia is induced by:

options.text: Change of amino acid in  <math> <mrow> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>α</mi><mo>−</mo> </mrow> </math> chain of haemoglobin
Change of amino acid in  <math> <mrow> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>β</mi><mo>−</mo> </mrow> </math> chain of haemoglobin
Change of amino acid in both  <math> <mrow> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>α</mi><mo>−</mo> </mrow> </math> and  <math> <mrow> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>β</mi><mo>−</mo> </mrow> </math> chain of haemoglobin
Change of amino acid in either  <math> <mrow> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>α</mi><mo>−</mo> </mrow> </math>  or  <math> <mrow> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>β</mi><mo>−</mo> </mrow> </math> chain of haemoglobin

solution.text: Sickle cell anaemia is a hereditary disorder of autosomal nature. It is caused  by mutation of the gene controlling  <math> <mrow> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>β</mi><mo>−</mo> </mrow> </math> chain of haemoglobin. It involves substitution of glutamine by valine.
